Aromatherapy and Diffuser in Palliative and End of Life Care/19027/1.0
Page  of
Introduction

There is growing support among patients and health care professionals for aromatherapy within palliative and end of life care (EoL). It is therefore important that aromatherapy is used responsibly in order to reduce risks of adverse effects. The following guidelines will support safety and best practice.

Palliative care is for patients with a life limiting condition whereas for the purpose of this guidance end of life (EoL) care is for those in the last days and hours of life. Both palliative and EoL involves providing holistic and best supportive care to enable individuals to live until the very last moments of life. There is growing evidence aromatherapy eases comfort through relaxation, supports symptom management and lifts moods (Tavares, M., 2003).
Individuals with a palliative diagnosis and those nearing end of life have a different set of needs than those who will recover. Aromatherapy can offer a sense of wellbeing at a time of uncertainty.
Aromatherapy is both a science and an art in which concentrated essential oils extracted from various parts of different plants are used for their therapeutic properties.
Aromatherapy cannot prolong life or cure a terminal illness but it can help make a situation more bearable and assist comfort and dignity to be a central part of nursing care.
The Trust is not promoting aromatherapy as an appropriate replacement for medical treatment but is to be used in addition to conventional treatment.

Aromatherapy is a complimentary therapy and there is some evidence to its efficacy. The Trust is not able to provide assurance that palliative / end of life patients will experience the claimed benefits. The Trust is not responsible in the event of lack of efficacy.

Options of aromatherapy include diffusers and gentle aromatic massage (hands and feet). Both offer a subtle yet effective way to reduce anxiety and support relaxation for individuals with a palliative diagnosis and those at the end of life.
Scope

Aromatherapy and diffusers are to be offered to adult inpatients at MEHT, who have been diagnosed palliative or at the end of life and have been referred to the HSPCT. Individual patients will be assessed and consented by the Hospital Specialist Palliative Care Team (HSPCT). Implementation of aromatherapy or diffuser will be offered to inpatients nursed in side rooms and not in open bays.
Therapy covered by this policy:
Aromatherapy gentle hand and foot massage;
Aromatherapy inhalation;
Aromatic fanning;
Diffuser.
Inclusion criteria
Palliative and end of life patients 18 years and over known to HSPCT;
Palliative and end of life patients who have been assessed, contraindications excluded and have given verbal consent;
Where a patient is unable to consent MCA must be completed;
Patients nursed in side rooms.
Exclusion criteria
Under 18 years;
Non palliative and end of life patients;
Palliative and end of life patients who do not give their consent;
Known allergy;
Where it is contraindicated;
Patients nursed in bays.
Identification of a patient

Referrals will be accepted by HSPCT for palliative and end of life inpatients at MEHT who have consented or have a MCA completed. Referrals to the HSPCT will need to be sent via Lorenzo with a clear rationale for request identified. The HSPCT will provide a holistic assessment of needs and prescribe aromatherapy if considered beneficial and in their best interests. Advice, recommendations and outcomes will be documented in their main notes.
Definitions

table_items.text: Essential oils are obtained through the ream of distillation or means of mechanical pressing to remove aromatic molecules from the plant material.
Carrier oils are used to dilute essential oils when used for massage.
Care and support of patients and those important to them diagnosed with a life limited illness and potentially in the last year of life.
Care and support in the last hours to days of life
Rubbing pleasant-smelling natural essential oils into the skin or breathing in their scent.
To gently press someone's hands and feet with regular repeated movements, in order to relax them and reduce
Diffusers are the movement of fluid from an area of high concentration, spreading out, ending with a lower concentration within the air.
…”Feeling good and functioning well and comprises an individual experience of their life” …DoH, 2014

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Role & Responsibilities of HSPCT within the Trust
Duties are to:
Provide guidelines for the provisions of aromatherapy and diffuser service at MEHT with regular reviews and updates;
Ensure there is a system in place to ensure safe effective service;
Responsible for holistic assessment of needs, planning and monitoring of aromatherapy and diffusers within palliative and end of life clinical practice;
Support educational needs of staff, patients and family/carer;
Supply of essential oils.
Registered Nurse
Duties are to:
NMC registered;
Responsible to maintain, improve and update professional knowledge and competence;
Recognise limitations within their professional competence;
Competent within the administration of aromatherapy and diffusers;
Mandatory training relevant to their role is updated.
Method of Application 1
Use of aromatherapy gentle hand and foot massage.
5.1.1 The maximum number of oils allowed in one mix is  The mix can be decided by the individual nurse and is dependent on the desired effect and preferences of the patient.
Table 1: Mixing and concentration

table_items.text: Number of drops in 5ml carrier oil
Number of drops in 10ml carrier oil
Number of drops in 15ml carrier oil
Number of drops in 20ml carrier oil

data.text: 5.1.2 The number of drops refers to the total number – for example:
If mixing 3 oil combinations with 15ml of grapeseed oil in a 2% concentration, the nurse can add:
2 drops of each oil ( 2 drops of Lemon oil, 2 drops of Lavender oil, 2 drops of Frankincense) Or
1 drop (Lemon oil), 3 drops (Lavender oil), 2 drops (Frankincense oil) or any combination as long as the total number of drops does not exceed the recommended dose quantity of the carrier oil.
Massage
5.2.1 Use the correct concentration of essential oil to carrier oil.
5.2.2 Areas to massage include:
Hands;
Feet.
5.2.3 Avoid massaging directly over veins / open wounds.
5.2.4 Do not use on post radiotherapy sites
Method of Application 2
Use of diffusers
Diffusers are an effective way to incorporate aromatherapy. Using a selection of essential oils can help in the management of symptom control, anxiety, depression, and odour;
Diffusers are easy to use and can help with symptoms being experienced by the patient / carer;
Check with the patient and relatives they are happy to have the diffuser, continue to monitor and re-evaluate needs;
Familiarise yourself with the instructions that come with the diffuser;
Fill the diffuser with water as per instructions - warm tap water is fine;
Use up to 6 – 8 drops of essential oil into the water ( Do not use carrier oil)
Switch on as per instructions;
Use in single occupant rooms only (not recommended for patients in shared facilities);
Ensure the diffuser is placed on a flat service;
Only use with natural essential oil supplied by HSPCT;
Ensure the diffuser is emptied and cleaned using Hospec liquid detergent before and after each use.
(Refer to Appendix 1)
List of Essential Oils to be used and their storage
Lavender : helps soothe aches and pain, relaxing/ calming, antibacterial
Frankincense : reduces pain, fear, anxiety , hyperventilation and panic attacks, is also a diuretic, antiseptic and expectorant
Bergamot : helps to relieve pain, spasms, fear, uplifting
Cypress : agitation
Spearmint : reduces nausea and vomiting, mental and physical fatigue and headaches
Patchouli : helps to relieve depression , relaxing, eases confusion, indecision and apathy it also helps with nerve sedation
Mandarin : Mild relaxant, helps reduce muscle spasm, anxiety , flatulence, constipation , stimulates and sedative, hypnotic and invigorating
Lemon : fatigue
Only this list of eight essential oils has been approved for use with palliative and end of life patients. Any essential oils not listed here are not to be used.
Carrier oils
The carrier oil of choice is grapeseed oil;
Oils will be purchased from an approved supplier ;
Oils will be stored in a locked dark cupboard in the palliative care office or on the ward;
Oils bought by patients or families will not be allowed as purity and quality cannot be guaranteed.
(Refer to Appendix 2)
Safety
General rules:
Do not take essential oils internally;
Neat essential oils should not be used directly on the skin;
Avoid contact with sensitive areas such as nose and eyes;
Wash hands thoroughly before and after massaging or preparing oils/equipment;
Keep essential oils away from flames;
Store correctly; Essential oils to be secured in a locked cupboard;
Any blend should be clearly labelled to avoid confusion;
All aromatherapy oils should be labelled when opened with date;
Pregnant staff less than  weeks pregnant should not use Clary sage oil.
(Refer to Appendix 3)
Dealing with Adverse Reactions
Wash skin with unperfumed soap and water to remove oil;
Keep area exposed to air to encourage evaporation;
Complete a risk event form electronically via Datix web.
Disposal of unused oil
Any remaining oil should be wiped out of dish using paper towels and paper towels disposed of in the clinical waste (yellow bag);
Wash dishes thoroughly using hospital grade detergent, rinse and dry;
Oils should not be given to patients or relatives to take home.
Administration

The NMC defines ‘medicinal products' as any substance or combination of substances which may be administered to human beings with a view to making a medical diagnosis or to restoring, correcting or modifying physiological functions is likewise considered a medicinal product. Therefore administration should be taken seriously and the following considered:
Identification of the patient;
Any known allergies;
The therapeutic uses of the oil, its recommended dosage, side effects, precautions and contraindications;
The plan of car;
The oils should be clearly labelled, in date and are of high quality from the approved chosen supplier;
Appropriate dosage and method of administration.
Training Requirements
All palliative care team nurses (members) are to attend specialist training on aromatherapy and diffusers with the lead complimentary therapist at Farleigh Hospice.
All palliative care team members and ward staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are updated to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
All registered nurses with the competence who have received appropriate training from the HSPCT.
Infection Control
All staff should follow Trust guidelines for infection prevention ensuring that they effectively decontamination their hands before and after each procedure.
Monitoring and Audit

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Clinical practice (PX administratio n and monitoring )

data.text: Approval and Implementation

This policy has been reviewed and approved by the medicine optimisation group and steering group and will be implemented with immediate effect from the agreement date. The document will be available electronically on the Trust intranet. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available from HSPCT.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to Appendix 4)

Appendix 1:
Additional information on methods of application

table_items.text: Gentle massage for hands and feet; use a 1% dilution for normal skin and a 0.5% dilution for sensitive skin. Massage should never be used on broken skin.

Diffusers can be used with up to 6 – 8 drops of essential oil. It is important to use intermittently and to regularly check if everyone is happy for it to continue. The diffuser will be for used only with patients assessed suitable and nursed in the side rooms. This is to prevent exposure to other patients.
1 drop of chosen essential oil on gauze swab/ tissue or cotton wool to inhale the aroma. Maximum of 2 drops in total for a combination of 2.
1-2 drops of essential oil onto a paper fan to cool down and calm down. One drop of spearmint onto a paper fan is good for nausea

table_items.text: In aromatherapy essential oils are safely used externally:
Aversion to smells Known sensitivities, allergies or reactions, to naturally perfumed products? Essential oils are for external use only

Store essential oils in a cool dark locked cupboard Citrus oils to be stored in a fridge Essential oils to be kept in a dark glass bottle, preferably brown Stored in a marked box Kept away from naked flames
